awd_titl_txt: Research in Harmonic Analysis and Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The principal investigator will undertake research in harmonic analysis and in the analysis of partial differential equations (PDE).  Harmonic analysis has played major roles in the pure and applied sciences since Fourier's seminal work on the theory of heat diffusion, continuing on with Schrodinger's equation in quantum mechanics. It underlies a diverse array of tools widely used in science and engineering, and it offers the promise of further applications in the future. The proposed research deals with foundational issues that may help to underpin future applications. In PDE, the project will study the long-time dynamical properties of several fundamental equations describing diverse physical phenomenon.  In particular, the nonlinear Schrodinger equation (NLS) models the transmission of data in fiber optic communication systems, and the Korteweg-de Vries equation (KdV)  models surface water waves as well as ion-acoustic waves in a cold plasma. The so-called fractional NLS is used as a model describing charge transport in bio polymers like DNA. Proposed problems on near-linear behavior and smoothing are directly motivated by real world engineering problems in fiber optic communication systems, and the methods used are likely to be useful in a range of applications.

In harmonic analysis this project focuses on problems in Euclidean spaces centered around Lebesgue norm inequalities. One subject of on-going research is the Fourier restriction phenomenon and its applications to problems in PDE and geometric measure theory. In the PDE component of the project, the focus is on the dynamical properties of linear and nonlinear dispersive equations. Subjects of interest here are dispersive decay and smoothing estimates for Schrodinger and wave equations, and their applications to the stability problem for their nonlinear counterparts. Another topic is the regularity properties of the solutions of nonlinear dispersive PDE such as the KdV equation, the Zakharov system, and the fractional NLS. The principal investigator will continue to explore the smoothing effect of the dispersive linear group on bounded domains, and he will study applications to the regularity properties and long-time dynamics of the nonlinear solutions. Proposed applications are on the existence and regularity of global attractors, dispersive quantization/Talbot effect, bounds for higher order Sobolev norms, and controllability.

por.por_cntn:
During the life of this award the PI and his students made contributions to the theory of linear and nonlinear
dispersive partial differential equations, and Fourier restriction estimates. In particular, he obtained dispersive
estimates for Schrodinger, wave, and Dirac equations, established smoothing estimates for Zakharov
system, nonlinear Schrodinger (NLS), fractional NLS, derivative NLS, and KP-II equations on Euclidean
spaces and on half spaces with nonhomogenous boundary data. Furthermore, he studied various
applications of smoothing such as the existence of fractal solutions (Talbot effect) and growth bounds for the
Sobolev norms. The efforts of the PI, his students, and his collaborators resulted in 18 research articles and
an introductory book in these areas.
Intellectual merit:
Strichartz and other dispersive estimates for linear partial differential equations (PDE) have wide range of
applications in nonlinear equations, and in particular in the stability problems of solitary solutions.
Understanding smoothing properties of nonlinear equations allows one to extend the results for the easier to
understand linear problems to the fully nonlinear counterparts. Growth of solutions, existence and structure of
global attractors, continuity properties of solutions are among such applications.
The Talbot effect and near-linear behavior are directly motivated by problems in engineering and physics.
The Zakharov system, the fractional NLS, and the derivative NLS equations are very well studied equations.
The Zakharov system describes the propagation of Langmuir waves in an ionized plasma. Fractional NLS is
a basic model equation in the theory of fractional quantum mechanics. It is also used as a model describing
charge transport in bio polymers like DNA. The wellposedness theory of
the derivative NLS equation is not completely understood even on the whole real line. On the half line with
boundary data the derivative NLS equation models nonlinear Alfven waves, weak nonlinear electromagnetic
waves in magnetic and dielectric media. PI's research outcomes on the regularity properties of these
equations contribute to a better understanding of the long time dynamics of the solutions.

Broader Impact:
The PI teaches and supervises graduate and undergraduate students as well as postdoctoral associates in
science and engineering programs in a large public school. The expertise the students gain from PI's efforts
contributes to their success as teachers, scientist and engineers in the future.
Two of PI's graduate students, S. Demirbas (joint with N. Tzirakis) and E. Toprak, obtained their PhD during
this award. Demirbas is a postdoc at the University of British Columbia. E. Toprak is a postdoc at Rutgers.
She received the 2019 Dissertation Prize of the Association for Women in Mathematics. PI's student, T.
Harris, wrote three research articles on Fourier restriction estimates for fractal measures and projection
theorems in this period. Another student of the PI, C. Huynh, is being trained on dispersive PDE and Talbot
effect.
The PI (with Tzirakis) ran two Illinois Geometry Lab project on Talbot effect. The projects employed eight
undergraduate students in math, physics, and engineering, and a graduate student, G. Shakan, as the
project leader. The students gained valuable experience in coding, linear and nonlinear dispersive equations,
and topics in geometric measure theory such as the fractal dimension.
Finally, the PI disseminated his research outcomes through seminars in multiple scientific meetings, and
through publications, providing easy access to research outcomes for a wide range of audience in sciences
and engineering.
